subject: Re: Book suggestions for translation.
msgSnippet: ... Yes you are correct-- the unicode techincally encodes characters and not graphemes-- I m a bit rusty on this and have got them mixed up-- its been a few
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Michael Everson <everson@...> wrote:
>
> On 30 Jul 2011, at 10:22, peter_r_guinness wrote:
>
> > The unicode standard was designed with future expansion in mind and so was made from the start to potentially handle *lots* of graphemes--
>
> The Universal Character Set encodes "characters", not "graphemes".
>
> > all the world's current symbols
>
> "characters"
>


Yes you are correct-- the unicode techincally encodes characters and not graphemes-- I'm a bit rusty on this and have got them mixed up-- its been a few years. Thanks for this correction.
However, I would like to point out to you that this sort of talk about differences between what is a character and what is a grapheme appears to me to exactly what Sid was referring to when he said that the previous unicode talk on this list confuses him.



>
> This is incorrect. I consider Quickscript to be a set of extensions to Shavian. Some preliminary work has been done working out what the extensions might be, but the activity was not followed through on, likely because people got interested in other things.
>
....
>
> No, it will be encoded as a set of extensions to Shavian.
>

I'm curious to know why you think QS should be an extension to Shavian. To me they are two different (but closely related) writing systems. Infact, to me the difference between QS and Shavian is to not vastly less then the difference between Latin and Greek (well the capital greek and latin letters anyway)
